newsitem.title: GERMANY: Kohl says will not sacrifice stability for euro.
newsitem.headline: Kohl says will not sacrifice stability for euro.

text.p: German chancellor Helmut Kohl said in an interview released on Sunday he would not sacrifice the stability of the European Union's planned single currency for the sake of the project as a whole.

He also said a strong European central bank was required to ensure the lasting stability of economic and monetary union (EMU), according to the transcript of the interview with ZDF television recorded at his holiday home in Austria.

"We don't want a weak euro," Kohl said. "Whoever believes that Helmut Kohl will give up the policy (of stability) out of enthusiasm for Europe and day-to-day factors...is wrong. That is a price I will not pay."

European leaders are due in spring 1998 to rule on which countries will qualify to join EMU. Kohl said that, in addition to the Maastricht treaty fiscal criteria, the sustainability of state finances would be a key factor.
"I am not just thinking of the criteria this or next year ... but of the concept of sustainability," Kohl said. "That is why we need an active and powerful European central bank."
He did not answer directly a question asking whether Germany would meet the Maastricht budget deficit goal of three percent of gross domestic product this year.
